title: Brisbane anti-Trump rally in King George Square | Cairns Post
text:
Brisbane anti-Trump rally in King George Square Clare Armstrong, The Courier-Mail 
ANTI-Trump protesters have gathered in Brisbane’s CBD to denounce the US President’s controversial immigration ban. 
More than 150 people attended the protest, which began in King George Square just after 5pm today. 
Several speakers addressed the crowd to condemn Mr Trump’s temporary ban on US immigration from seven predominately Muslim countries. 
Mr Trump’s now-infamous phone call with Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull was also discussed. 
“If anyone’s going to be rude to our Prime Minister it’s going to be us,” one speaker said. 
Many speakers compared Mr Trump’s rhetoric with that of One Nation leader Pauline Hanson. 
“We have our own Donald Trump and she goes by the name of Pauline Hanson,” activist Oula Shihan said. USA: Iranian man makes triumphant return to LA after challenging 'Muslim ban' 1:12 
Emotions ran high as Iranian national Ali Vayeghan was welcomed by family members at Los Angeles International Airport, Thursday. Vayeghan was initially turned away from the airport last Friday under US President Donald Trump executive order barring immigrants from seven Muslim-majority countries. Vayeghan's family had been waiting to welcome him at the same terminal when he was detained for several hours by immigration officials, who then sent back him back to Iran. Vayeghan was only allowed to return to the US after the American Civil Liberties Union successfully filed a legal action against the federal government. On Sunday, US District Judge Dolly M. Gee ruled in favour of Vayeghan, stating that he had a legal travel visa and had been approved for a green card. The Judge added that not allowing his return was unconstitutional and would do him grave harm. Trump's executive order blocks citizens from 'countries of concern,' namely Syria, Iran, Iraq, Somalia, Yemen, Sudan and Libya from entering the US for 90 days. The order, which includes a blanket ban on Syrian refugees as well as nationals, which initially included US green card holders, has caused havoc at US and international airports and around the world. Many Middle Eastern travelers have been held at customs and refused travel as a result. Trump has since stated that he wants to give priority to Christians over Muslims who are trying to escape the Syrian conflict. MANDATORY CREDIT: March And Rally Los Angeles February 3rd 2017 /video/video.news.com.au/News/ USA: Iranian man makes triumphant return to LA after challenging 'Muslim ban' 
During the protest Oumama Hadj Mohamed spoke about her experience as a Muslim woman and first-generation Australian with immigrant parents. 
“Our dignity, our character, our rights, our very faith have all been under attack,” she said. 
Members of the crowd carried placards with slogans such as, “Oi Trump, pull your head in” and “Love trumps hate”. 
At the end of the speeches the group left Mr Turnbull a voice message chanting “bring them here”. 
After the speeches the crowd marched through Brisbane’s CBD chanting anti-racist slogans. 
The Brisbane protest took place in conjunction with stop work activities and university campus protests across the country.
